Award.AwardTitle: Low-Temperature Epitaxy of Gallium Nitride Thin Films

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to elucidate the mechanisms responsible for a low-temperature growth process of high-quality gallium nitride (GaN) films with low thermal impact on substrates. The project will develop a laser-assisted metalorganic vapor phase epitaxy (L-MOVPE) process that can enhance the chemical reactions in epitaxy of GaN thin films with low substrate temperatures. A wavelength-tunable CO2 laser, with a wavelength tunability from 9.2 to 10.9 micrometers, will be used to resonantly excite NH3 molecules for promoting chemical reactions to facilitate and maximize the GaN epitaxy process. The research approach progresses from mechanism study of resonant excitations of precursor molecules, to growth of high-quality GaN epilayers on different substrates for a wide range of applications. Deliverables include an L-MOVPE system configured for synthesis of GaN thin films and other functional materials, documentation of research results, and engineering student education.

If successful, the results of this research will realize low-temperature growth of high-quality GaN films with high energy-coupling efficiency and low thermal impact on substrates. In terms of applications, the proposed method can provide a novel approach of GaN epitaxy on sapphire or SiC substrates for electronic, optoelectronic, chemical, and biological applications. The successful completion of this project will impact the scientific research of laser-controlled chemical processes by resonant excitation of precursor molecules. Practically, the proposed method is expected to provide a novel approach to synthesizing functional materials at lower temperature with high energy-coupling efficiency. The research results will also contribute to productivity improvement, energy savings, and environmental protection in related industries that rely on high-temperature chemical processes to fabricate compound semiconductors. Graduate and undergraduate students will benefit through involvement in the research and classroom instruction. The engagement of K-12 students and teachers in this project will also establish new partnerships between the University and K-12 schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Group III nitride direct band gap semiconductors have demonstrated superior physical and electronic properties and thus have attracted much attention in the field of optoelectronic devices such as laser diodes (LDs), solar cells and full color or white light-emitting diodes (LEDs). A high Young's modulus makes gallium nitride (GaN) more appropriate than silicon for resonant devices, and the pyroelectric properties of GaN offer possibilities for MEMS and NEMS energy harvesting devices with novel functionalities. GaN may have other advantages, including high dielectric strength, high operating temperature, high current density, high speed switching, and low on-resistance. These features make GaN useful in high voltage and high power electronics. High electron mobility enables applications of GaN-based high-electron-mobility transistors (HEMTs) in wireless infrastructure, high-frequency communication systems, active electronically scanned array radars, and aerospace systems.

Researchers at the University of Nebraska–Lincoln (UNL) developed a technique using laser-assisted metalorganic chemical vapor deposition (LMOCVD) for growing GaN on various surfaces, such as silicon and sapphire at low temperatures. The growth of crystalline GaN films requires high temperatures in conventional techniques such as metal organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD, ~950-1100oC), molecular beam epitaxy (MBE, ~800oC), and hydride vapor phase epitaxy (HVPE, ~ 750oC). This high growth temperature sometimes causes adverse effects in GaN films which degrade the efficiency of GaN-based devices. In this work, a new process of laser-assisted MOCVD synthesis was developed for growing crystalline GaN films at low temperatures. By deploying resonant vibrational excitation, efficient amount of energy (supplied by an infrared CO2 laser) was coupled into specific molecules, ammonia (NH3), to enhance the growth process. Through resonant excitation of the NH3 molecules and imparting a high kinetic energy to the precursors by a CO2 laser at the wavelength 9.219 µm, most NH3 and TMGa molecules were dissociated. High substrate temperatures needed for dissociating precursor molecules were eliminated. C-oriented crystalline GaN films were grown on sapphire (α-Al2O3) substrates at low temperatures of 250oC to 600oC.

Moreover, coupling the energy into different states of ammonia molecules leads to obviously different GaN growth rate, surface morphology, and GaN crystalline quality. The differences are ascribed to the fine tune of chemical species and corresponding populations in the reaction system. Considering an average GaN growth rate less than 1 micrometer per hour (μm/hr) in MBE and 2-4 μm/hr in a commercial MOCVD process, an extremely high growth rate of 80 μm/hr was achieved in LMOCVD. A high growth rate helps reducing the cycle time in device fabrication. The Nebraska team also deployed the LMOCVD processing for the rapid growth of m-plane-oriented GaN on the Si substrates at low growth temperatures.

Under the NSF support, two graduate students received systematic multidisciplinary training on GaN growth, material characterization, optical spectroscopic analyses, mass spectrometric analysis, and infrared laser processing during the project period. Multidisciplinary knowledge established in this project was distributed via teaching (ELEC 973 Introduction to Nanotechnology), undergraduate research experience programs, journal publications (6), conference presentations (3), external collaboration, and outreach activities.
